intro: Dendranthema coronarium, commonly known as the buttonweed or crownflower, is a flowering plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It belongs to the Asteraceae family, which includes daisies and sunflowers, and is characterized by its composite flower heads. The plant typically grows to a height of about 30–60 cm, featuring basal leaves that are lance-shaped and covered in fine hairs. Its flowers are small and yellow, forming a dense cluster that resembles a crown, hence its common name. Dendranthema coronarium is often found in meadows, roadsides, and disturbed soils, and it is known for its medicinal properties in traditional herbal medicine.
